tasks.title: Line and Load Regulation Sweep
description: ### Setup
Connect the SMPS input to a programmable DC power supply and the output to an electronic load.
Use a the eLoad or DMM to measure the output voltage. ('remote sense' may be neccesary)
Define a set of input voltages spanning the full operating range.
Define a set of output currents spanning the full operating range.
*As much as possible, you should minimize load on the converter from other things on its output (microcontrollers, ither ICs, etc).  Some additional load is fine, but this should be minimized*
### Procedure
For each defined input voltage:
1. Set the input voltage to the defined point.
2. Sweep the output current from 0 A (no load) to maximum rated current in steps (e.g., 10–20%).
3. Record the following data at each load point.
### Data to Collect
- Input voltage (VIN)
- Input Current (IIN) *if combining efficiency*
- Output voltage (VOUT)
- Output current (IOUT)
- Calculated deviation from nominal output voltage
### Pass/Fail Criteria
- Output voltage remains within specified tolerance (e.g., ±2% of nominal) across VIN and IOUT sweep.
- No oscillations, dropout, or abnormal behavior observed during any sweep.

tasks.title: Switch Node Characterization
description: ### Setup
Connect an oscilloscope probe to the SMPS switch node (between MOSFET and inductor or diode).
Use a high-bandwidth probe (≥500 MHz recommended) with short ground connection or spring tip adapter.
Operate the SMPS under various input voltages and load conditions.
### Procedure
1. Power the SMPS at nominal input voltage and apply nominal load.
2. Capture switch node waveforms at rising and falling edges of the MOSFET.
3. Vary input voltage across operating range and repeat captures.
4. Sweep output load from light load to full load, recording waveforms at each point.
### Data to Collect
- Rise time and fall time (slew rates) of the switch node transitions.
- Peak-to-peak ringing amplitude and frequency components after each transition.
- Evidence of subharmonic oscillation, instability, or jitter in the switching pattern.
- Switching frequency stability across VIN and IOUT conditions.
### Pass/Fail Criteria
- There's no hard and fast pass/fail criteria.  This will depend on voltage levels, and nearby components.
- As much as possible you should try to reduce any ringing or over/undershoot
- Make sure to check for signs of instability, subharmonic oscillation, or excessive jitter.

tasks.title: Efficiency
description: *This testing can sometimes be merged with 'Line and Load Regulation Sweep' if the parasitic load is low enough*
If not combined, you should run the same type of sweep but ensure that parasitic load is at it's absolute minimum.
If relevant (converter active during sleep), repeat this testing to focus on light load operation.

tasks.title: Educated Short Circuit
description: ### Setup
Connect the SMPS input to a programmable DC power supply and the output to an electronic load.
Use a the eLoad or DMM to measure the output voltage. ('remote sense' may be neccesary)
Define a set of input voltages spanning the full operating range.
### Procedure
For each defined input voltage (VIN_min, VIN_nom, VIN_max):
1. Set input voltage to the target level.
2. Slowly ramp the load current upward until the converter enters protection or limiting mode.
3. At each steady-state current step, allow thermal stabilization of the power stage.
4. Record output voltage, output current, and component temperatures once stable.
### Data to Collect
- Input voltage (VIN).
- Output current (IOUT) and output voltage (VOUT).
- Steady-state temperatures of all key power components.
- Point of current limit engagement or shutdown behavior.
### Pass/Fail Criteria
- Converter enters current limit or protection mode without catastrophic failure.
- Temperatures remain within rated limits under sustained stress.
- No uncontrolled oscillation, runaway, or permanent damage observed.
- Recovery behavior after overload is consistent with design intent.

tasks.title: Transient Response
description: ### Setup
Connect the SMPS input to a programmable DC supply covering the full operating VIN range.
Connect the output to an electronic load (eload) capable of generating fast current pulses.
Attach an oscilloscope with both voltage and current probes at the output.
### Procedure
For each defined input voltage:
1. Configure the eload to apply step changes in current.
2. Use at least two step magnitudes: e.g. 30% → 70% of Imax and 10% → 90% of Imax.
3. Trigger the oscilloscope on the output current.
4. Record output voltage and current waveforms for both rising and falling load steps.
### Data to Collect
Oscilloscope screenshot showing the following
- Input voltage (VIN).
- Step current levels (start % and end % of Imax).
- Output voltage waveform showing undershoot, overshoot, and ringing.
- Output current waveform shape during the transient.
- Recovery time to return within regulation tolerance.
### Pass/Fail Criteria
- Output deviation within tolerance (e.g., ±5% of nominal voltage).
- Recovery time meets spec (e.g., <1 ms).
- Ringing amplitude acceptable and well damped.
- No major oscillation, instability, or resets observed.

tasks.title: Inductor Saturation Characterization
description: ### Setup
Desolder the inductor from one pad and 'tombstone' it upright.
Solder a short wire loop from the free pad back to the PCB to complete the circuit.
Attach a current probe around the loop to directly measure inductor current.
Use an oscilloscope to capture voltage and current waveforms.
### Procedure
1. Operate the SMPS at different VIN and load conditions (light to heavy load).
2. Record inductor current waveforms using the current probe.
3. Capture scope screenshots at each condition.
4. From VIN, VOUT, fsw, and measured ripple current, calculate effective inductance.
5. Plot inductance vs load to observe approach toward saturation.
### Data to Collect
- Inductor current waveforms (scope screenshots).
- Ripple current magnitude at each operating point.
- Calculated effective inductance values.
- VIN, VOUT, load current, and fsw for each test condition.
### Pass/Fail Criteria
- Inductor remains linear (no signs of sharp current distortion or saturation) in operating range.
- Effective inductance stays above design minimum across tested load currents.
- No excessive heating, noise, or instability observed.
